column6: | Thinner (3.3mm) flash only now up to 512[[gigabyte|GB]] although standard goes up to 128[[petabyte|PB]] since CF 5.0

column1: | Thicker (5.0mm) older flash but usually [[Microdrive]]s up to 128 PiBref name="cf-spec-50" / !--hard drives usually use the smaller unit--

column6: |XQD form factor (38.5 mm × 29.8 mm) PCIe 3.0 x2 (20 GB/s) NVMe
| Very slim (45.0×37.0×0.76mm) no [[wear leveling]] controller up to 128MB. This particular example shows the write protect sticker (the silver disc).

column6: | Small (32×24×2.1mm) DRM up to 4GB. (2GB and 4GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See [[Secure digital#SDSC cards above 1 GB|Article]])

column4: | Compact (21.5×20×1.4mm) DRM up to 4GB. (2GB and 4GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See [[Secure digital#SDSC cards above 1 GB|Article]])
| Subcompact (15×11×1mm) DRM up to 4GB. (2GB and 4GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See [[Secure digital#SDSC cards above 1 GB|Article]])

column4: | Same build as SD but greater capacity and transfer speed 4GB to 32GB (not compatible with older host devices).
| Same build as miniSD but greater capacity and transfer speed 4GB to 32GB. 8GB is largest in early-2011 (not compatible with older host devices).
| Same build as microSD but greater capacity and transfer speed 4GB to 32GB.(not compatible with older host devices)
| Same build as SD/SDHC but greater capacity and transfer speed 32GB and higher. Standard goes up to 2TB (not compatible with older host devices).

column5: | Same build as microSD/microSDHC but greater capacity and transfer speed 32GB and higher. Standard goes up to 2TB (not compatible with older host devices).

column4: |Same build as SD/SDHC/SDXC but greater capacity and transfer speed. Standard goes up to 128 TB (not compatible with older host devices).
|Same build as microSD/microSDHC/microSDXC but greater capacity and transfer speed. Standard goes up to 128 TB (not compatible with older host devices)

column6: | Slim and narrow (50×21.5×2.8mm) optional DRM up to 128MB

column4: | Slim and narrow (50×21.5×2.8mm) swifter optional DRM up to 4GB
| Compact (31×20×1.6mm) swifter optional DRM up to 32GB

column6: |Packages the flash memory currently soldered in shipping smartphones into a removable card form factor. Uses the SCSI command set including queuing. The electrical interface makes use of [[differential signaling]] which enables high bus speeds and robustness under noisy conditions and reduced pin count (compared to parallel bus alternatives such as [[UHS-I]]).

column5: | style="text-align: center" | [[File:Geil David 1GB AB.jpg|110px]]br /small(not to scale)/small
column6: | Universally compatible across most non-mobile computer platforms their greater size suits them better to file transfer/storage instead of use in portable devices
